Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office a familiar background. As an architect, I was expected to keep projects moving, but my style was relaxed—I checked in on timelines, nudged things along, but rarely micromanaged. Today, though, my mentee, Sarah, hovered at my door, uncertainty written on her face. She wanted advice about whether to take on a new responsibility in her current project. Normally, I’d offer a few words and let her decide, but she seemed genuinely lost, looking for more than my usual casual guidance.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the client meeting was in an hour, and I hadn’t double-checked the team’s progress on the latest design revisions. If I didn’t review the updates now, we might miss a critical detail. But if I brushed Sarah off, I’d fail her as a mentor. The weight of both roles pressed on me—one demanding I be present and thorough, the other expecting me to be available and supportive. I felt torn, caught between the needs of my team and the needs of someone looking up to me, unsure which expectation to meet first.
